abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This edited volume brings together international authors to explore how cities around the world are implementing their commitment towards the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). To achieve sustainability, cities choose their own goals and develop the necessary governance and resourcing mechanisms to achieve their objectives. This book highlights the innovative ways cities can plan their implementation by drawing on comprehensive research and literature reviews. Case studies from around the world, including North and South America, Europe, Asia, and Africa, describe examples of various cities’ governance mechanisms, resourcing strategies, and implementation strategies. By showcasing these case studies, cities worldwide can emulate, transform, and execute their own vision drawing on the examples and pathways laid out by their peers. The book concludes with a comparative analysis of UN SDG implementation, contrasting the approaches and enabling communities worldwide to learn from one another and choose strategies that meet their local needs. This book will be of great interest to students, researchers, and professionals of urban sustainability, planning, smart cities, and sustainable communities. It will also be useful for city and government stakeholders including policy makers, economic development corporations, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: What is implementation and what should we know about implementing our city’s sustainable development goals? Are there solutions that cities can emulate or amend to suit their needs? This is a case study approach with several cities that are tackling the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs) and presenting what they did and how they did it in this book. This first chapter explains concepts of sustainability and what we mean by implementation. It then provides an overview of what you can expect from the various chapters of this book.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: Cities have significant challenges in meeting their sustainability goals, hence governance and resourcing are critical issues that will determine whether outcomes can be achieved. Governance is concerned with the structures, processes, norms, values, and rules through which public affairs are managed in a transparent, participatory, inclusive, and responsive manner. It is about how power is distributed and shared, how policies are formulated, priorities set, and stakeholders made accountable. It includes a diverse range of actors in decision-making processes as well as the formal and informal structures set in place to make and implement decisions. In this context, city governance is the process by which governments and stakeholders collectively decide how to plan, finance, and manage urban areas. This needs to encompass the multiple ways in which individuals and institutions, whether public, private, or civil, plan and manage the common affairs of the city in a continuing process where conflicting or diverse interests are accommodated, and cooperative action is taken. In this chapter we explore several theoretical and applied examples of governance and resourcing.

citation-title.titletext: Un Voluntary Local Reviews By Cities

affiliation.ce:source-text: Sylvie Albert is a Professor of Leadership and Strategy, and a past Dean of the Faculty of Business and Economics and Continuing Education, at the University of Winnipeg, Canada
Manish Pandey is a Professor of Economics, and the Acting Dean of the Faculty of Graduate Studies, at the University of Winnipeg, Canada

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In this chapter, we look at the practices of the various cities who have provided a Voluntary Local Review (VLR) to the UN in 2021–3 to explore commonalities, differences, and areas of innovation. The chapter will use the data captured from 40 VLR reports and present its findings in various formats to inform the reader on similarities and differences in approaches to projects and programmes that were chosen, based on regions and community size, and outlining the more popular tools used to meet the challenges of the UN Sustainable Development Goals.

affiliation.ce:source-text: Diana Alarcón has extensive experience with international organizations and recently served as Chief Advisor to the Mayor of Mexico City Claudia Sheinbaum (2018–23). At the United Nations (UN) she was Head of the Policy and Development Analysis Unit at the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (DESA). She also worked for ten years at the Inter-Amer ican Development Bank (IDB), as well as with the United Nations Develop ment Programme (UNDP) and the International Labour Organization (ILO). Diana holds a PhD in Economics from the University of California, River side, and has taught at several universities in Mexico and the United States.

affiliation.organization: El Colegio de la Frontera Norte
affiliation.ce:source-text: Rocio Canudas was an Adviser in the General Coordination of Advisers and International Affairs of the Government of Mexico City from 2018 to 2023. Holding a PhD in Social Sciences (El Colegio de la Frontera Norte), a Master of Arts in Economics (San Diego State University), and a Bachelor’s degree in economics (National Autonomous University of Mexico – UNAM), this author held academic positions as a Professor at the Faculty of Political and Social Sciences of the UNAM (2011–18); Designer, coordinator, and instructor for online courses on Methodologies for Evaluation of Develop ment (INDES-IDB, 2006–18); Full-time Professor at the INDES-FON CODES Training Program for Social Managers in Peru (2004–7); Resident Coordinator and Professor at the INDES Training Program for Social Man agers in Honduras (2002–4); Full-time Researcher at the Center of Socio economic Research (CISE) of the Autonomous University of Coahuila (UAdeC), Mexico (1996–2001); and full-time researcher at the Institute of Social Sciences of the Autonomous University of Durango (UJED), Mexico (1977–96).

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that define Agenda 2030 are fully reflected in the 2019–2024 Government Program of Mexico City (Program 19–24), as established in international agreements signed by the Mexican Government. Program 19–24 reflects citizens’ interests and demands as expressed in the public consultations held during then-candidate Claudia Sheinbaum Pardo’s campaign to become the first elected woman Mayor in Mexico City. In a city marked by inequality, the overriding concern in implementing government programs has been ensuring every person living in the city has access to all human rights, such as health, education, efficient and safe mobility, housing, water, and sanitation, among others. In that sense, the United Nations SDGs have been very useful in formulating policies addressing the three dimensions of sustainability – social, economic, and environmental. The two editions of the city’s Voluntary Local Review published in 2019 and 2021 indicate how Agenda 2030 and other global agendas are related to every policy area. In this chapter, we focus attention on two specific issues: gender equity and environmental sustainability. By discussing the implementation of programs in these two priority areas, we illustrate how public policies in Mexico City are helping to reduce inequalities. A rights-based approach to policy implementation has helped reduce inequalities and advance the vision of an economic, social, and environmentally sustainable city.

citation-title.titletext: Measure, Mobilize, Connect Los Angeles and the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals

affiliation.ce:source-text: Madeline Baer is an associate professor of Diplomacy & World Affairs at Occi dental College. Her research combines insights from international relations and comparative politics, with a focus on state implementation of global norms, the politics of water policy, and the evolution of state foreign policy as it relates to economic and social human rights. She is the author of Stemming the Tide: Human Rights and Water Policy in a Neoliberal World (2017), which examines the interaction of states and markets in the water sectors of developing countries. Her current research project examines cities as actors in international relations, with a focus on cities that are implementing global norms on climate change, sustainable development, and gender equity. This research is closely connected to her work with the Los Angeles Mayor'sOffice of International Affairs, which is partnered with Occidental College’s Young Initiative on the Global Political Economy, to implement the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) in the city of Los Angeles. Her research appears in Studies in Comparative Interna tional Development, the Journal of Human Rights, Third World Quarterly, International Studies Perspectives, Human Rights Review, and the International Journal of Water Governance

Heidi Nichols Haddad is an associate professor of Politics and coordinator of the International Relations programme at Pomona College in Claremont, CA. Her research sits at the intersection of the fields of international relations and inter national law. It studies the global governance of human rights through examin ing interactions between states, non-state and sub-national actors, and intergovernmental organizations and their effects on norms, law, and judicial mechanisms. Her book, The Hidden Hands of Justice: NGOs, Human Rights, and International Courts (2018), is the first comprehensive analysis of non-gov ernmental organization (NGO) participation at international criminal and human rights courts. Her research on NGOs and courts has also explored the dynamics of NGO mission expansion, the role of advocacy groups in pressuring for sexual violence prosecutions at international criminal tribunals, and the jus tification of anti-NGO foreign funding laws. Her current research project exam ines cities in international relations and explores the localization of international norms to cities and city engagement with international human rights monitor ing. Her research and op-eds have been published, or are forthcoming, in Eur opean Journal of International Law, Human Rights Quarterly, Law & Society Review, Human Rights Review, Journal of Human Rights, Global Governance, International Studies Perspectives, and The Washington Post.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The City of Los Angeles is at the vanguard of localizing and implementing the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The decision to implement the SDGs grew out of existing commitments and plans, including the city’s Green New Deal, and Los Angeles’s participation in the global C40 Cities network. Individual people with global connections and vision were crucial to the decision to begin adapting and localizing the SDGs in Los Angeles. The city pursued collaborations with other cities, think tanks, foundations, and local colleges and universities, which were central to the SDG localization efforts. The mayor’s team developed a four-phase methodology for implementing the SDGs and chose to report on all 17 goals. The city launched online data reporting portals and produced two Voluntary Local Reviews (VLRs). These VLRs explain the process of adapting the original goals and targets to the local context; provide detailed mapping of city programs, policies, and actors that contribute to the goals; report on progress; and highlight connections with community partners. By innovating and piloting new approaches to SDG implementation, Los Angeles emerged as a leader in the burgeoning city-to-city networks and convenings related to city implementation of the SDGs, and city participation in global governance more generally.

citation-title.titletext: Sustainable Welfare And Development In Gladsaxe

affiliation.ce:source-text: Line Vind is Senior Advisor in strategic management at the Municipality of Gladsaxe in Denmark. Armed with an MA in International Studies and an MA in Public Governance, she works with strategic management and gov ernance in the public sector and is at the forefront of initiatives to integrate the UN’s global goals into the overall strategic development of the munici pality of Gladsaxe. This implies new opportunities for building bridges across the various administrative areas through strategic initiatives and actions practice, e.g. via a cross-cutting strategy network. Externally, Vind also explores the potential in strengthening value creation through interaction and partnerships with citizens, businesses, and other organizations or actors.

Line Vind is Senior Advisor in strategic management at the Municipality of Gladsaxe in Denmark. Armed with an MA in International Studies and an MA in Public Governance, she works with strategic management and gov ernance in the public sector and is at the forefront of initiatives to integrate the UN’s global goals into the overall strategic development of the munici pality of Gladsaxe. abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: Gladsaxe is a municipality within the Greater Copenhagen conurbation in Denmark with about 70, 000 inhabitants. It has a long-term vision of integrated social, environmental, and economic sustainability and a municipal strategy with six cross-cutting strategic goals each integrating several of the global SDGs: A good place to live, Children shaping the future, Equal opportunities, Health and well-being, a Business-friendly city with job growth, and Climate action. Within this framework, the departments determine how each local goal is to be achieved in practice with the SDGs serving to raise the bar and build bridges across sectors and municipal policies, as well as with businesses, civil partners, and citizens. In this way, the SDGs are grounded in municipal priorities, rather than separate strategies, providing a holistic lens and focus for local sensemaking and action by leaders, staff, and partners. The mixed steering governance mechanisms integrate Public Administration, New Public Management, and Societal Resilience paradigms/perspectives. This way political legitimacy is assured with the strategy being the basis for municipal budgets structured around the triple bottom-line: people, planet, and prosperity. The strategy is translated through the management processes throughout the organization and was achieved through partnerships. Also, there is a clear message of ‘license to act’ incentivizing and encouraging employees to develop sustainable solutions and activities in their work, which contributes to shared commitment. Since 2017, Gladsaxe’s overall experience integrating relevant SDGs into its strategy and work in practice has been very good. Nevertheless, there were initial challenges in starting up because of the complexity of the wicked problems addressed by the SDGs and in making the SDGs relevant to the Danish welfare model. This also applied to discussions on measurement so as not to fall into the technocratic trap that sees indicators themselves as the purpose rather than simply as guides towards achieving the real goals. However, after several loops in discussions with municipal politicians and leaders, a virtuous circle of pragmatic approaches was found that fitted local contexts and were able to integrate the SDGs in addressing local issues.

citation-title.titletext: Navigating Sustainability In Shah Alam Implementing Sustainable Cities

affiliation.ce:source-text: Kamalia Azma Kamaruddin holds a Doctorate of Philosophy in Information Technology and Quantitative Sciences from Universiti Teknologi MARA (UiTM). She currently serves as a senior lecturer in Information Systems at the College of Computing, Informatics and Mathematics in UiTM Shah Alam, Malaysia. Kamalia Azma has authored multiple research papers, focusing her work on e-government, requirements engineering, and system development. Her research is dedicated to advancing the understanding of these critical areas within the field of information systems and information technology.

Annie Syazrin Ismail TPr. is a retired Senior Assistant Director cum Sustain able Development Officer from the Shah Alam City Council, and boasts a distinguished career spanning 23 years in government service. She has held pivotal roles at both the state and local levels, including notable positions at the Department of Town & Country Planning in Selangor. Recognized for her fervent advocacy of sustainable development, Annie Syazrin holds a Bache lor’s degree in Town & Regional Planning (Hons) and a Master’s degree in Heritage and Conservation Management. She is a Chartered Town Planner accredited by the Malaysia Board of Town Planners and has served as a Council Member of the Malaysian Institute of Planners (MIP). Currently, she channels her expertise as a freelance consultant under her professional body, continuing her commitment to advancing sustainable practices and commu nity development initiatives

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: Among the numerous cities globally implementing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), the city of Shah Alam has been playing a key role in championing SDGs at the local level in Malaysia. This chapter encapsulates the city’s proactive dedication to sustainable urban development within the framework of the SDGs. Shah Alam’s journey involves a meticulous adaptation and implementation of the SDGs, aligning them with the city’s needs and priorities. Led by the Shah Alam City Council (MBSA), initiatives include the preparation of the Shah Alam SDGs Roadmap, engaging stakeholders, and integrating the SDGs into existing policies and community projects. The process involves aligning local actions with the SDGs, fostering an eco-friendly urban environment, community resilience, and effective governance. Challenges such as project continuity, private sector engagement, and resource limitations are evident, yet ‘low-hanging fruits’ are identified, offering opportunities for immediate positive impact. The city’s SDG strategy integrates seamlessly with broader policies, indicating a bottom-up approach aligned with state and federal policies. The Shah Alam model showcases structured implementation and reporting, serving as a potential framework for cities sharing similar governance structures. This article highlights Shah Alam’s achievements, challenges, and the multifaceted approach employed in embracing sustainable urban development practices

citation-title.titletext: Japan's Minamata: Challenges And Innovations In Sustainable Development goal implementation And Sustainability Beyond Borders

affiliation.ce:source-text: Lynn Thiesmeyer was Professor of Environmental Information at Keio University, Japan, from 1995 to 2022, where she headed the Sustainable Devel opment Graduate Project, and is currently Professor Emerita and Senior Researcher at the Keio Global Research Institute. She has worked as an advisor and co-researcher with the Asia-Pacific Economic Commission (APEC), with the UNDP and United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO), and with the MEDICI Framework of the EC, and was Research Advisor to the Mekong Institute of Thailand. Her publications include Human Insecurity in East Asia (ed., 2009), Informal and Illegal Movement in the Upper Greater Mekong Subregion (2010), articles on environmental and economic policy within ASEAN, and book chapters on security, space, and socio-economic and socio-ecological impacts of large scale development projects in rural and borderland areas of the Upper Mekong.

Lynn Thiesmeyer was Professor of Environmental Information at Keio University, Japan, from 1995 to 2022, where she headed the Sustainable Devel opment Graduate Project, and is currently Professor Emerita and Senior Researcher at the Keio Global Research Institute. abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: Minamata, a small city in southern Japan, has been widely regarded as a miraculous example of a town that rebounded from a long-term environmental and health disaster to become “Japan’s No. 1 Eco-Town.” The original challenge to its sustainability originated in toxic industrial contamination from local and transboundary economic development. Its recovery, and locally formulated sustainability, have had positive spillover effects that include the models it provides for areas suffering similar disasters across the globe. For a small and seemingly isolated area like Minamata, prioritizing its own local, traditional strengths along with transboundary interactions is crucial. Although Minamata has historically been well-connected outside its area, recent work on sustainability has not tackled the supra-provincial and supra-national aspects of sustainability. Further, Minamata has long been economically disadvantaged. Questions of how this challenge affects progress towards achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, as well as the preservation of Minamata’s own locally crafted sustainability, are addressed here along with some trans-local, transboundary aspects of sustainability.

citation-title.titletext: The City Of Malmö: A star in the sustainability sky

affiliation.ce:source-text: Emma Björner, PhD, is a Researcher in Marketing at the School of Business, Economics and Law, University of Gothenburg, and Senior expert at IKED. Her work and research focus on the branding and development of sustainable places, destinations, and organizations, with a focus on co-creation, inclusion, digitalization, culture, and food. Emma has published several articles and book chapters on these topics and presented her work in various international conferences.

affiliation.organization: International Organisation for Knowledge Economy and Enterprise Development
affiliation.ce:source-text: Ingrid Andersson is a senior business executive and sustainability strategist, drawing on experience as a serial entrepreneur with a strong track record of establishing private companies as well as non-profit associations. At Interna tional Organisation for Knowledge Economy and Enterprise Development (IKED) Ingrid is responsible for advancement of analysis and practical applications of digital enablers, devised to underpin citizen co-creation of nature-based solutions, within the EU-funded URBiNAT project under the Horizon 2020 umbrella. For more than 20 years, Ingrid engaged in the development of “zero-emission” eco-houses and vibrant local community development. With Japanese partners, she established the “Swedish Ecov illage” in central Nagoya, Japan, featuring the application of tailor-made pre manufactured houses exported from Sweden, and comprising a self-reliant renewable energy and water ecosystem. An experienced mentor in the field of start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), Ingrid engages extensively in enterprise development with a focus on global challenges including health, food, water, and energy. She takes a particular interest in the transformation of business ideas into high-impact operations, drawing on innovative product development, customer-focus, and engaging suppliers in co-creation in a dynamic international business environment. Among other present positions, Ingrid is Vice President of the Global Forum. She was key to the development of the 2022 edition of the Global Forum which took place in Muscat, Oman. She is a board member of the Qatar Investment Fund and member of the OECD-MENA (Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development – Middle East and North Africa) Women’s Business Forum.

Sylviane Toporkoff is the President and Founder of the Global Forum/Shaping the Future, an international think tank on technology, sustainability, andhumanity created in 1992. She also founded, in 1994, ITEMS International, a company specialized in strategic digital consulting. Sylviane counts more than 25 years of experience in communication, IT, consultancy, and project manage ment, with an international network of expertise in Digital Government, Smart Cities, and smart information. While holding her position as Professor at Paris University, she was the cofounder of the Institute of European Studies, Paris 8, France. Also, she is the Founder of the European Education New Society Asso ciation (ENSA), an association working on the future of education and Infor mation and Communication Technologies (ICT). Sylviane is an economist with a Doctorate in Economics from the University of Paris I Panthéon-Sorbonne, France. She is also the author of many publications and a speaker in interna tional conferences in the field of ICT. In her free time, Dr Toporkoff is an accomplished sculptor. Sylviane has been granted the prestigious “Chevalier of the Legion of Honor” and the medal of “Arts, Sciences and Letters”

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This chapter illustrates Malmö’s implementation journey towards the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). It reviews the city’s transformation from a major hub of heavy industry, through its exposure to harsh external shocks, to evolving into an epicentre for innovation and sustainable living with a young and diverse population. Malmö was early to announce an ambitious agenda to fulfil the SDGs, applying them as guiding principles for local development work. The chapter centres on five themes standing at the core of Malmö’s sustainability efforts, namely inclusion, education, food, mobility, and coastal transformation. The chapter outlines Malmö’s commitment to developing courageous leadership, long-term vision, and co-creation.

citation-title.titletext: Cape Town: Using the Sustainable Development Goals to unlock development potential

affiliation.ce:source-text: Marc Watum is an African development specialist with backgrounds in con sulting and finance. He advised over 30 governments across the Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) region as the founding chairman of the Vision 2030 Fund, a sustainability agenda for Africa that invests in climate adaptation and mitigation ventures that particularly address food and water system insecurities. Marc also founded Vertex Ecosystem (thevertex.org) in 2017 as a climate tech incubator – he has already supported over 1, 000 sustainable business entrepreneurs with the objective of making African smallholder farmers, women, children, and the marginalized investment-ready. Marc also has experience in African commodities trading, mining, supply chains, and logistics, championing projects that are carbon neutral and regenerative. Marc holds an MSc in Globalisation and Development from the School of Oriental and African Studies and is the organizer of key summits including MENA Innovation 2018 (under patronage of the Egyptian Ministry of Information & Technology), Vertex Summit 2018 in London, the Global Impact Summit 2019 in Nairobi (supported by Kenya National Chamber of Commerce & Industry), and the Vision 2030 Food Systems Summit Dialogue in 2021 in partnership with the UN. To date Marc has been called to deliver addresses at the Global Forum (where he is an advisor), COP27, the World Economic Forum, the Feed Africa Summit, and several UN meetings including the URBINAT Innovate4Cities Conference and the UN Environ ment Assembly

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This chapter presents the challenges and opportunities facing Cape Town as the city reports its progress toward achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) through the publication of its 2021 Voluntary Local Review (VLR). This investigation is governed by five key questions: 1.What is the current scope of South Africa’s SDG initiatives? 2.Which issues surround the governance of Cape Town’s SDG interventions? 3.Cape Town is the only VLR-submitting city in the country. Does subscribing to this level of evaluation help to produce better SDG implementation processes? 4.How do contemporary development finance frameworks contribute to today’s sustainability challenges in South Africa? 5.How does innovation help municipalities to steer away from continued SDG programme underperformance? South Africa’s development pathway as a post-apartheid state is analysed, highlighting the political, social, and economic fundamentals of the country’s success (or lack thereof) in the pursuit of the SDGs. Focus areas include development finance, debt, aid, policy externalisation, political and social justice, as well as culture as they apply to the shaping of SDG intervention projects. The role of Entrepreneurial Empowerment Ecosystems is discussed, presenting how expertise in incubation, acceleration, investment readiness programmes, and increased venture capital-styled financing at the early stage of localised social enterprises may optimise SDG projects in the city.

citation-title.titletext: A Grassroots Approach To Understanding Sustainable Development Goals For A Voluntary Local Review In Kelowna

affiliation.ce:source-text: Kusum Wijesekera is an engineer. Kusum has spent 15 years working in var ious industries from aerospace to construction. She is currently working on infrastructure projects for the Government of Nunavut. She worked with the British Columbia Council for International Cooperation (BCCIC) to develop Canada’s first Voluntary Local Review (VLR), for the community of Kelowna. She hopes this VLR will provide a guide and encourage other communities to develop VLRs, advocating and supporting progress for mar ginalized groups (indigeneity, ethnicity, gender, income status, etc.). As an Engineers Without Borders Fellow, she worked in Ghana trying to address food insecurity through commercial insect farming. Prior to that, Kusum was the Chair of GECCO, a Chapter of BCCIC working to support sustainable local and global change using the SDGs as a framework. She has also served as Vice-President and Director of Programs for Her International, an orga nization facilitating community development in Nepal and Canada by empowering women and girls through programmes such as scholarships and micro-credit.

affiliation.organization: Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions (PICS) (Climate research institute at UBC)
affiliation.ce:source-text: Sara Muir is a programme manager with the Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions (PICS) at the University of British Columbia (UBC). Sara assists in the administration, management, and planning of climate change research, initiatives, programmes, and events at UBC, and beyond. A landscape archi tect by training and a registered planner by practice, Sara is driven by a desire for fairness and peace amongst healthy, resilient, diverse communities – all within a stable climate. Her everyday work aims to connect people – be they researchers, policy makers, community members – together to co-create, plan, and implement mitigation and adaptation solutions to climate change. She’s also been exploring how cities can use the UN SDGs as a framework for local government planning and policy development to advance climate change solutions and sustainability at the community level

affiliation.organization: City of Kelowna (Municipal government where Danielle Noble-Brandt works)
affiliation.ce:source-text: Danielle Noble-Brandt is the department manager of Policy and Planning for the City of Kelowna. She is an urban planner passionate about creating places where people flourish, and in her current capacity she shares her vision for cities of the future and her passion for walkable, healthy, and connected communities that enhance public life. Over the past 15 years, Danielle has advanced policy direction on commencing a Healthy City Strategy, Climate Action Plan update, 2040 Official Community Plan, and various strategies for revitalizing neighbourhoods. Her planning practice is characterized by an emphasis on collaborations across sectors and advancing the built environ ment to improve health, equity, and connectedness for communities. She has an Honours degree in Science from UBC and a Master’s degree in Environ mental Studies, Planning, from Wilfred Laurier University

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: In March 2021, British Columbia Council for International Cooperation (BCCIC), Global Empowerment Coalition of the Central Okanagan (GECCO), City of Kelowna, and Pacific Institute for Climate Solutions (PICS) at the University of British Columbia launched Canada’s first Voluntary Local Review (VLR) for the community of Kelowna, Canada. Like any community-wide planning initiative, Kelowna’s VLR process was complex and very rewarding, with several challenges and learning moments along the way. Of note, the entire VLR was largely carried out by a team of volunteers – with no formal funding, the team’s commitment required incredible perseverance and discipline to harness such a collective effort. Fostering collaboration and accountability among partners and agencies across highly complex, controversial topics such as racism and poverty, and other systemic and intersectional issues, although uncomfortable at times, was a focus. Our team’s Truth and Reconciliation journey involved careful reflection and consideration of Indigenous Peoples’ perspectives, priorities, and interests, and proved an important journey of (un)learning. As the Kelowna VLR process did not culminate in a Council-endorsed document, City staff had to take liberties to ground the VLR work alongside other existing municipal projects and tease out alignments where feasible. The final deliverable is a report aiming to bring the Sustainable Development Goals closer to the people of Kelowna and that aligns to the framework as a tool for sustainability planning, policy, and implementation.

citation-title.titletext: Barcelona's approach to achieving the sustainable development goals

affiliation.ce:source-text: Chiara Farinea is an Italian architect and urban planner. She obtained her PhD in Urban Planning at IUAV (Venice), a Master’s in Advanced Archi tecture at IAAC (Barcelona), and the Architecture University Degree at Politecnico di Milano (Milan). She has been a member of the Association of Architects of Genova for more than ten years. Her research focuses on environmental planning and design. She is currently Head of European Projects at the Advanced Architecture Group Department at IAAC; her position includes being a coordinator and scientific personnel in several EU projects targeted at education, research, development, and implementation and being faculty in IAAC educational programmes. She has been a contracted pro fessor of Urban Planning at the Faculty of Architecture of Genoa. Moreover, she is a founding partner at Gr.IN Lab art group, exhibiting installations in 2015 at Venice Arsenale and Turin for the Italia-China Art Biennale. Among other roles, her previous work experience includes being Project Manager at D’Appolonia (Genoa), Project Manager/Senior Architect at Open Building Research architectural office, and Junior Architect at KSP Engel und Zim mermann architectural office in Berlin

affiliation.organization: Vrije Universiteit Brussel VUB University in Belgium
affiliation.ce:source-text: Fruzsina Csala holds a double Master’s degree in Urban Studies and Geo graphy from the Vrije Universiteit Brussel and the Université Libre de Brux elles, and a Bachelor’s degree in Art and Design Theory from the MoholyNagy University of Art and Design in Budapest. With a diverse inter disciplinary background, she has experience across various sectors related to urban affairs, including sustainable urbanism, mobility, public engagement, culture-led urban development, and public art. Currently, she is a Researcher and Project Manager at the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia (IAAC) in Barcelona, where she contributes to the Horizon Europe Projects of GreenIn Cities and HeritAct. Prior to her current role, among others, Csala held positions as a Blue Book trainee at the EC DG REGIO and as a Public Engagement Project Manager at the Budapest Development Agency.

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: The Barcelona City Council has successfully aligned its municipal plans and strategies with the global Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by establishing targets that are relevant both at the urban scale and within the specific geographical, socioeconomic, and political context of the city. This chapter introduces Barcelona’s approach to adopting the SDGs. The chapter is organized into four sections. The introduction provides an overview of the city’s recent urban development and sustainable strategies prior to the Agenda 2030. The subsequent section delves into the details of the Barcelona Agenda 2030. The third part focuses on SDG 11 – Sustainable Cities and Communities, offering a detailed examination of the process of localizing the SDGs through concrete initiatives and projects. In this section, the CO-MIDA and RESPIRA projects funded by the Barcelona City Council are introduced as examples of how innovation on the urban scale is aligned with the broader scope of the SDGs, extending beyond SDG 11. The projects were developed by diverse consortiums in which the Institute for Advanced Architecture of Catalonia (IAAC) had leading roles alongside other non-municipal stakeholders. The chapter concludes with a summary of Barcelona’s exemplary approach to sustainability, highlighting strategic leadership, inclusive stakeholder engagement, integrated budgeting and monitoring, and a longstanding commitment as key elements.

citation-title.titletext: The european support and coordination for sustainable development goal voluntary local reviews

affiliation.organization: European Commission EC Joint Research Centre
affiliation.ce:source-text: Alice Siragusa is an architect and urban planner. She worked at the EC Joint Research Centre from 2015 to 2023, contributing to different projects on urbanization and urban and regional development. Her research interest focuses on urban policies for sustainable development. She holds a PhD in Regional and Urban Planning from Sapienza University of Rome, and a Master cum laude in Architecture and Urban Design from the University of Roma Tre

affiliation.organization: European Commission EC Joint Research Centre
affiliation.ce:source-text: Cecilia Bertozzi is an architect and urban planner with extensive experience and understanding of the built environment. Her 18 years’ work links research, practice, and strategic perspectives. She has worked as a project leader for international architectural firms, spanning from urban renewal competitions to public–private partnerships and covering the whole design and construction process; for UN-Habitat on urban governance innovations; and in refugee camps with the Red Cross, with the overarching focus of researching and implementing integrated and locally adapted solutions for more sustainable and resilient urban futures. At the Joint Research Centre of the European Commission (EC) since 2021, she has explored the links between urban policies and sustainable agendas, analysing the local imple mentation of SDGs in EU regions and cities.

affiliation.organization: European Commission EC Knowledge Centre for Territorial Policies
affiliation.ce:source-text: Paula Proietti holds a Bachelor and MSc in Economic and Social Sciences from Bocconi University, Italy. She specialized in Urban and Regional Sci ence, receiving her PhD cum laude in 2019. Her research cuts across human and economic geography, political economy, and public policy. In 2019 she joined the EC where she contributes to the Knowledge Centre for Territorial Policies focusing on sustainable development, spatial inequality, poverty, housing, migration, and development finance.

affiliation.organization: Joint Research Centre JRC of the European Commission EC Research organization of the EU
affiliation.ce:source-text: Iraklis Stamos is a researcher with an engineering background, specializing in sustainable development, climate change, mobility, and innovation. He has dedicated over 16 years to the field, including roles in academia, private and research sectors, and international environments. He currently holds a pivotal position at the Joint Research Centre of the EC, where he leads projects focused on localizing and implementing SDGs in European regions and cities. His extensive experience also includes managing Urban Innovative Actions in France, evaluating EU-funded projects, and contributing to transportation and logistics through the development of Horizon 2020-funded projects. His scholarly achievements are complemented by a PhD in Engineering and numerous publications in peer-reviewed journals, underlining his contribution to the field of sustainability

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: TThe Joint Research Centre (JRC) of the European Commission (EC) has been running one of the first attempts by an intergovernmental organization to provide local governments implementing the UN’s 2030 Agenda with guidance on how this could be undertaken more successfully. The aim is to support the monitoring and possibly the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by providing an inspirational framework of indicators for the monitoring that could be relevant specifically for European cities, as well as providing overall support on the various technical aspects that must be considered when preparing Voluntary Local Reviews (VLRs). The main output of the JRC in this respect is the European Handbook for SDG Voluntary Local Reviews. Its first version was published in 2020 when only a few VLRs had been published in Europe. Since then, a growing number of local governments are engaged in this exercise. To facilitate the learning from these experiences, the JRC organized advanced training and coordination sessions with several European cities. These training sessions were the occasion to share experiences and good practices and to provide cities with additional insights and guidance. In 2022, a new edition of the European Handbook was published. This revision includes the refinement of indicators and methods for monitoring, aspects of the Handbook that cities found problematic or complex, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic. The new Handbook of local SDG monitoring addresses related challenges and opportunities, expanding the definition of VLRs from output-oriented to process-oriented. Additional activities include in-depth analyses of SDG interlinkages and implementation and monitoring of the European ‘Leave No One Behind’ principle at the local level.

affiliation.ce:source-text: Sylvie Albert is a Professor of Leadership and Strategy, and a past Dean of the Faculty of Business and Economics and Continuing Education, at the University of Winnipeg, Canada
Jeremy Millard is an independent researcher affiliated to the Danish Techno logical Institute as a Senior Analyst and to several European universities as a Senior Visiting Research Fellow
Manish Pandey is a Professor of Economics, and the Acting Dean of the Faculty of Graduate Studies, at the University of Winnipeg, Canada

abstract.publishercopyright: © 2025 selection and editorial matter, Sylvie Albert, Jeremy Millard, and Manish Pandey; individual chapters, the contributors
abstract.ce:para: This chapter summarizes city Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) localization lessons and good practices from the preceding chapters including reflections from chapters 2 and 3. We have extracted several examples of implementation strategies from the city chapters to illustrate. Cities were provided with the following seven steps in the implementation cycle so that they would work from a common framework and report on their experience with examples of practices: 1.Mapping, vision, and gap analysis: this compares the current city context (mapping) with what the city wishes to do (vision) and proposes what could be done (gap analysis). 2.Selection of projects: based on what can be done in terms of who, what, when, how much, and why. 3.Feasibility: examines real and possible constraints, risks, opportunities, etc. 4.Engagement and communication: staff and stakeholder onboarding, incentives, etc. 5.Roles, responsibilities, resourcing, and governance: how projects will be implemented in practice including action plans, budgeting, etc. 6.Evaluation mechanisms: descriptions of how projects, each SDG, and the overall vision can be evaluated. 7.Monitoring: systems, feedback, and adoption.
